title: Proof Setup
content: We begin by assuming $\sqrt{2}$ is rational, meaning it can be written as $p/q$ where $p$ and $q$ are coprime integers (no common factors). This is the standard setup for a proof by contradiction.

title: Even Squares Imply Even Roots
content: A key lemma: if $n^2$ is even, then $n$ must be even. The contrapositive is easier to prove: if $n$ is odd, then $n^2$ is odd. Since $(2k+1)^2 = 4k^2 + 4k + 1 = 2(2k^2 + 2k) + 1$.
mathContext: This lemma relies on the closure of odd numbers under multiplication. The product of odd numbers is always odd.

title: The Irrationality of Square Root of 2
content: From $p^2 = 2q^2$, we deduce $p$ is even. Writing $p = 2k$, we get $4k^2 = 2q^2$, so $q^2 = 2k^2$, making $q$ even. But both $p$ and $q$ being even contradicts coprimality. Therefore, no such $p, q$ exist.
mathContext: This is an instance of infinite descent: if a solution exists, a smaller one must exist, ad infinitumâ€”impossible for positive integers.
